responses.overtake: Use one word for "overtake": "Suddenly, the child overtook the runners and went on to place first." "overtake", "over take", "over-take", "overtook", "over took", "over-took" overtake
responses.hobnob: "Hobnob" is one word: "Elected officials would hobnob with journalists at the annual gathering." "hobnob", "hob nob", "hob-nob", "hob-nobbed", "hob nobbed", "hobnobbed", "hob-nobbing", "hob nobbing", "hobnobbing" hobnob
responses.runoff: Write "runoff" as one word when you're using it as a noun: "The candidates are headed for a runoff." Use two words for the verb: "He was able to run off with the money before anyone noticed the bag was missing." "runoff", "run-off", "run off" runoff
responses.ig: Don't capitalize "religious right" when referring to the conservative coalition of Christians that has played a role in American politics since the 1970s: "The speech was written to appeal to the religious right." Capitalize “Moral Majority” when referring to the organization associated with the religious right: "He was a fundraiser for the Moral Majority in the 1980s."
responses.groundbreaking: Use one word for "groundbreaking": "The study described a groundbreaking discovery." "groundbreaking", "ground breaking", "ground-breaking" groundbreaking
responses.hr: Use two words for "through line": "The unique use of color is the through line in the artist's work."
responses.suit: "Lawsuit" is one word: "She filed a lawsuit against the company." Avoid using just "suit" when you mean "lawsuit."
responses.breakin: Do not use a hyphen in "heartbreaking" or "heartbroken": “She found the Game of Thrones finale heartbreaking.”
responses.pac: Use "Conservative Political Action Conference" on first reference to the annual gathering, but "CPAC" is acceptable in headlines, tweets and on subsequence references.
responses.dc: Use one word for "windchill": "The windchill reached a new low on Friday." Don't capitalize "windchill factor" or "windchill warning."
responses.onto: "Onto" is one word: "The designer did some last-minute tweaks before the models walked onto the runway." "onto", "on to" onto
responses.quarterfinal: Use one word for "quarterfinal" and "quarterfinalist": "The win means the team will advance to the quarterfinals." "quarterfinal", "quarter-final", "quarter final", "quarterfinals", "quarter-finals", "quarter finals", "quarterfinalist", "quarter-finalist", "quarter finalist", "quarterfinalists", "quarter-finalists", "quarter finalists" quarterfinal
responses.lighthearted: "Lighthearted" is one word: "Surprisingly, her wedding vows were very lighthearted." "lighthearted", "light-hearted", "light hearted" "lighthearted", "light-hearted", "light hearted" lighthearted lighthearted
responses.matchmaker: Use one word for "matchmaker" and "matchmaking": "They met through a friend who prided herself on her matchmaking skills." "matchmaking", "match-making", "match making", "matchmaker", "match-maker", "match maker" matchmaker
responses.siv: In the active voice, the subject of the sentence performs the action: "Annenberg Media published her story." In the passive voice, the sentence's subject is the person or thing being acted on: "Her story was published by Annenberg Media." Putting your sentences in the active voice can improve your writing, but there are use cases for the passive voice.
responses.longtime: "Longtime" is one word as an adjective: "She's bringing her longtime boyfriend to the wedding." Otherwise, it's two words: "It has been a long time since I studied for a standardized test." "longtime", "long time", "long-time" longtime
responses.aid: Hyphenate "laid-back": "She said she admired Sara's laid-back personality, even when things got stressful."
responses.pot: Use one word for "hotspot" when referring to internet access: "She needed to find a Wi-Fi hotspot." Otherwise, use two words: "They avoided the city because it was a COVID-19 hot spot."
responses.rack: The correct phrase is "nerve-racking," not "nerve-wracking": "He finds election night too nerve-racking, so he decided to watch a movie instead of the news."
responses.sti: Use "Keystone XL pipeline" or "Keystone XL oil pipeline" on first reference to the controversial project that would expand the existing Keystone pipeline system: "Biden canceled the presidential permit for the Keystone XL oil pipeline on his first day in office."
responses.kickoff: Write "kickoff" as one word when using it as a noun: "The students arrived early so they wouldn't miss kickoff." "kick off", "kickoff", "kick-off" kickoff
responses.lineup: Use one word for "lineup" when you're using it as a noun: "Injuries continued to affect the team's starting lineup." Use two words for the verb: "People started to line up at 4 a.m."
responses.peacekeeping: "Peacekeeping" is one word: "They were hosting a special discussion about global peacekeeping efforts." "peacekeeping", "peace-keeping", "peace keeping" peacekeeping
responses.suite: "Suite" is a group or collection: "The hotel suite looked nothing like it did in the pictures." "suite", "suit" "suite", "suit" suit, suite suit, suite
responses.sun: Use "Sundance Film Festival" on first reference to the annual festival held in Park City, Utah: "The movie won an award at the Sundance Film Festival last year."
responses.icu: You can use "Agriculture Department" on the first reference when writing about the U.S. Department of Agriculture. If you want to use "USDA" on the second reference, make sure your audience will know what you are referring to. Do not capitalize "department" when you're not using "agriculture" before or after it: "She resigned her position at the department a short time later."
responses.anytime: "Anytime" is one word when used as an adverb: "Call me anytime!" Otherwise, it's two words: "I let it go to voicemail any time he calls." "anytime", "any time" anytime
responses.stake: Use "stake" for phrases such as "stake a claim," "at stake," "stake one's life" and "stake out": "'I'd bet a lot of money, but I wouldn't stake my life on it,' she said." "stakeout", "stake-out", "stake out", "steakout", "steak-out", "steak out", "staked a claim", "staked-a-claim", "stake a claim", "stake-a-claim", "stake one's life", "stake-ones-life", "stake my life", "stake-my-life", "at stake", "at-stake", "at steak", "at-steak", "steaked a claim", "steaked-a-claim", "steak a claim", "steak-a-claim", "steak one's life", "steak-ones-life", "steak my life", "steak-my-life", "stake her life", "stake his life", "steak her life", "steak his life" stake
responses.tenet: A "tenet" is a basic principle or belief, while a "tenant" is an occupant who leases or rents a house, apartment, etc. "tenet", "tenets", "tenant", "tenants" tenet, tenant
responses.drunk: "Drunk" and "drunken" are both adjectives ("drunk" is also a noun), but "drunken" implies a habitual state, while "drunk" does not: "She was tired of his drunken tirades." "She was killed by a drunk driver." "drunken", "drunk" drunk
responses.covid: Do not refer to COVID-19 variants by the countries where they were first identified. Instead, use the letters of the Greek alphabet designated by the World Health Organization. The WHO updates its list here: https://www.who.int/en/activities/tracking-SARS-CoV-2-variants/. Capitalize the Greek letter but not the word "variant": "U.S. health officials are increasingly worried about the Delta variant of COVID-19."
responses.nbd: "NBD" is a common abbreviation for "no big deal." It's generally accepted lingo on the internet, so it's acceptable on first reference on social media. In other copy, write out the phrase. Do not add periods in any context, and if you're quoting written material, format it as you see it written: "'If you can't come tonight it's nbd,' she texted back." "n.b.d.", "nbd" NBD
responses.instagram: Capitalize "Instagram Stories" and "Instagram Reels": "She posted an Instagram Reel for the first time."
responses.mifepristone: Don't capitalize "mifepristone," a medication used to end a pregnancy: "The judge's ruling on mifepristone put the drug's future in question."
responses.racist: Do not hyphenate "antiracist" when describing the effort to actively fight against racism and racist policies instead of merely abstaining from racist actions: "They were working to ensure the curriculum was antiracist."
responses.media: "Comedian" is acceptable for a funnyperson of any gender: "She had always wanted to be a comedian."
responses.washington: Capitalize "March on Washington" when referring to the 1963 civil rights demonstration and to subsequent marches named after it: "Organizers have a March on Washington planned for later this month." The historic March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom was on August 28, 1963.
responses.collab: You can use "collab" (no period) on first reference for "collaboration," especially if you're writing about music or quoting a source. However, if you think it will cause confusion, use "collaboration." "collab", "collab." collab
responses.zamboni: "Zamboni" is a registered trademark and is used to refer to many ice resurfacing machines, whether they are made by Zamboni or not. Capitalize the name when referring to an actual Zamboni machine. Otherwise, use “ice resurfacing machine” or "ice resurfacer": "They couldn't wait to get back on the rink and nearly ran into the ice resurfacer." "zamboni", "ice resurfacer", "ice resurfacing machine" Zamboni
responses.antebellum: Don't capitalize "antebellum" unless it's part of a proper noun: "Her paper focused on the economy of the antebellum South."
responses.massacre: "Massacre" describes a mass or unusually cruel murder, and unfortunately it is often an appropriate term for news stories. However, these events are horrible enough on their own and don't require the use of emotionally charged words, so limit use of the term as a noun. The adjective "mass" will often do. For example, use "mass shooting" instead of "shooting massacre." Avoid use of "massacre" as a verb. Instead of, "He massacred 50 people in the theater," write, "He killed 50 people in the theater." "massacre", "massacred" massacre
responses.beatbox: Use one word for "beatbox," "beatboxing" and "beatboxer": "They made their name beatboxing before landing a record deal."
responses.bacteria: "Bacteria" is the plural form of "bacterium." However, it's OK to use with singular verbs: "The study indicates that gut bacteria is linked to mental health." "bacteria", "bacterium" bacteria
responses.tv: "TV" (no periods) can often be used on first reference. Spell out "television" if that is what a person said in a quote or if it is part of a proper noun. "tv", "t.v.", "television" TV
responses.federal: Don't capitalize "federal" or "government" unless you're using it as part of a proper noun: "The trial will start Tuesday since federal courts are closed Monday for the holiday." Use "Federal Reserve" on first reference to the U.S. central banking system: "The Federal Reserve raised interest rates." You can use "the Fed" in shortened copy and on subsequent references: "The Fed's decision to raise interest rates has been widely criticized."
responses.imminent: "Imminent" means happening soon: "With the votes finally secured, the bill's passage is imminent." "Eminent" means prominent or conspicuous: "Their parents are both eminent academics." There's also "immanent," which means inherent.
responses.via: Consider your audience before using abbreviations or terms that are common on the internet but not as common in formal writing. Pick one below to get more specific guidance.
responses.narcan: Narcan is the brand name of a device that delivers naloxone, which is used to reverse opioid overdoses. If you are sure the device in question is Narcan, you can use that term. Otherwise, use "naloxone" to refer to the antidote: "The paramedics administered naloxone in attempt to revive the patient." "narcan", "naloxone" Narcan
responses.hackathon: Use one word for "hackathon": "The cofounders met at a hackathon." "hackathon", "hack-a-thon", "hack a thon", "hackathons", "hack-a-thons", "hack a thons" hackathon
responses.hollywood: Hollywood is a neighborhood in Los Angeles, not a city. Avoid implying that it is: “Hollywood stars will gather at the Dolby Theatre in Los Angeles on Sunday for the Oscars." There is a city of West Hollywood, however: “The Standard’s West Hollywood location will close for good next week.”
responses.marijuana: “Marijuana” and “cannabis” are often used interchangeably, but marijuana is the flower of the cannabis plant. Some people avoid use of “marijuana” because of its racist history, and you should consider an alternative such as “cannabis” or “weed” when appropriate. Don’t capitalize any of the terms: “Her mom smoked pot well into her 70s.” “THC” is short for tetrahydrocannabinol, the active ingredient in the drug, and is acceptable on first reference. “CBD,” short for cannabidiol, is another component of marijuana, though it does not produce a high. “CBD” is acceptable on first reference: “CVS has begun selling CBD oil.” "marijuana", "cannabis", "weed", "pot", "reefer", "ganja", "hashw", "hashish", "hash oil", "hemp", "THC", "t.h.c.", "CBD", "c.b.d."
responses.champagne: Champagne is not a generic term to refer to sparkling alcoholic beverages. It refers only to such beverages from the Champagne region of France and should be capitalized. Other beverages sharing Champagne's qualities but not from that region should be called sparkling wine.
responses.democratic: Do not capitalize "democratic socialist": "Some fear that Sanders' self-identification as a democratic socialist will hurt his chances in the general election."
responses.supermajority: "Supermajority" is one word: "There is virtually no chance the bill will make it past the California Legislature's Democratic supermajority." "supermajority", "super majority", "super-majority" supermajority
responses.shah: Like other titles, "shah" is capitalized when it comes directly before a name but not when it comes after a name or in general usage.
responses.giddyup: Though the word "giddyup" originated as "giddap" and is also spelled "giddyap," use the "u" for clarity: "'Giddyup, let's go!' he yelled as he tried to get everyone out the door."
responses.bahamas: "Bahamas" and "the Bahamas" are both acceptable for the island chain in the Atlantic Ocean near the Caribbean: "They won a trip to the Bahamas." "bahamas", "bahama" Bahamas
responses.genderqueer: "Genderqueer" refers to people who do not identify as strictly male or female. It is always one word: "As someone who is genderqueer, they were unable to complete the form because it only contained binary gender options."
responses.selfie: The term "selfie" is widely known, so it's acceptable on first reference with no explanation required: "They took a selfie in front of the mural." "selfie", "selfy", "selfies" selfie
responses.roofie: "Roofie" is slang for the generic sedative flunitrazepam, or Rohypnol, which is commonly associated with date rape. It's acceptable to use on the first reference if it's likely that your audience is familiar with the word. If not, use it only as appropriate with an explanation: "She thought someone put a sedative, commonly called a roofie, in her drink." It's common for "roofie" to be used as a verb, but opt for clarity by only using it in direct quotes: "Harrison said his friend was 'roofied and passed out' shortly after they left."
responses.whose: "Whose" is the possessive: "Whose backpack is this?"
responses.vr: Write out "virtual reality" on first reference and use "VR" on subsequent references: "Virtual reality headsets don't have to be expensive, but they are still one of the biggest barriers to wider VR adoption."
responses.samaritan: Capitalize "Samaritan" in the phrase "good Samaritan." "samaritan" good Samaritan
responses.sidepiece: "Sidepiece" is one word: "She wore a floral sidepiece in her hair for her wedding." Avoid using the term to refer to people unless someone identifies themself that way. "sidepiece", "side-piece", "side piece" sidepiece
responses.preventative: "Preventive" and "preventative" mean the same thing, but "preventive" is technically correct: "She practices preventive medicine."
responses.wimbledon: You can use "Wimbledon" on all references to the tennis tournament, as long as you think the context will be clear to your audience: "She's hoping to making a comeback at Wimbledon." The proper name is "The Championships, Wimbledon," and the tournament is sometimes called the "Wimbledon Championships."
responses.amputation: Use "person with amputation" instead of "amputee:" "He worked as a podiatric surgeon and was a big advocate for people with amputations." "person with amputation", "amputee", "amputees", "people with amputation", "people with amputations" amputation
responses.burqa: A "burqa" is a garment worn by some Muslim women that covers the body and face. "She was a member of a group that was working to change burqa bans." "burqa", "burka" burqa
responses.superintendent: Only capitalize "superintendent" when it's a formal title coming directly before a name, and do not hyphenate it: "She was recently promoted to school district superintendent." "superintendent", "super intendent", "super-intendent" superintendent
responses.mustache: "Mustache" and "moustache" are both correct spellings of the word, but "mustache" is more common in American English: "He grew a mustache after he left for college." "mustache", "moustache", "moostache" mustache
responses.reverend: When "reverend" is used as a religious title directly before a name, it can be abbreviated as "the Rev." Spell it out and do not capitalize it in other uses: "He went to the reverend for advice." "reverend", "reverends", "the rev.", "the rev" reverend
responses.dox: Only capitalize "orthodox" when referring to a specific branch of faith: "As a member of the Orthodox Catholic Church, he'll celebrate Easter about a month later." Capitalize "Orthodox Christmas" and "Orthodox Easter." In all other cases, do not capitalize: "He had rather orthodox practices."
responses.host: "Host" is not capitalized, even when it comes directly before a name: "'Late Show' host Stephen Colbert insulted President Donald Trump in his monologue last night." Use "host" for all genders. "host", "hostess" host
responses.sogi: "SOGI" stands for "sexual orientation and gender identity." Use the full term on first reference and use the acronym sparingly: "The organization is pushing the government to collect data on sexual orientation and gender identity." "SOGI", "s.o.g.i.", "sexual orientation and gender identity" SOGI
responses.zionism:
Zionism is an ideology and movement advocating for Judaism as both a religion and nationality. "Zionist" is not synonymous with "Jewish" or "Israeli." Capitalize the term in all uses: "The candidate said she was attacked for her Zionist beliefs." "antizionism", "anti-zionism", "anti zionism",
"antizionist", "anti-zionist", "anti zionist",
"antizionists", "anti-zionists", "anti zionists",
"zionism", "zionist" Zionism
responses.meetup: "Meetup" is one word when you're using it as a noun: "She went to a meetup after class." It's two words if you're using the phrase as a verb: "She left class to meet up with her friends." "meet up", "meet-up", "meetup", "meet ups", "meet-ups", "meetups" meetup
responses.ruble: Use "ruble" in all references to Russia's currency: "The skirt cost 950 rubles." (Its code is RUB.) "ruble", "rubles", "rubel", "rubels" ruble
responses.maskless: "Maskless" is one word: "He was still uncomfortable being maskless even though he'd been vaccinated." "maskless", "mask-less", "mask less" maskless
responses.jerusalem: Don't refer to Jerusalem as Israel's capital, and let the city stand alone instead of writing, "Jerusalem, Israel." The United States recognizes Jerusalem as Israel's capital, but that's not the view of the international community as a whole. Capitalize "East Jerusalem": "Palestinians want East Jerusalem to be the capital of their future state."
responses.muslim: Use "Muslim" to refer to an adherent of the religion of Islam. "Islamic" can be used as an adjective: "She's a leading Islamic scholar." "islamic", "Muslim", "Islamist" Muslim
responses.word-of-mouth: Hyphenate "word-of-mouth" when you're using it as an adjective: "The company's early growth came mostly from word-of-mouth recommendations." Don't capitalize when you're using the phrase as a noun: "News of the party spread by word of mouth."
responses.juneteenth: "Juneteenth" is acceptable on all references to the June 19 holiday that celebrates the end of slavery in the United States: "They didn't have work on Juneteenth because it's a federal holiday." "black national independence day", "black independence day", "juneteenth", "jubilee day", "freedom day", "emancipation day", "juneteenth independence day", "african american independence day", "june teenth" Juneteenth
responses.subzero: "Subzero" is one word: "They weren't expecting subzero temperatures."
responses.kickstarter: Use "Kickstarter" to refer to the crowdfunding site: "They raised money through a Kickstarter campaign." "kickstarter", "kick-starter", "kick starter" Kickstarter
responses.kinda: Only use "kinda" if you are quoting someone. Otherwise, use "kind of."
responses.wannabe: "Wannabe" is one word, no hyphen: “The clique of girls at school saw Jackie as a wannabe.” "wannabe", "wanna be", "wanna-be" wannabe
responses.decathlon: Do not capitalize "decathlon": "She's part of the effort to get women's decathlon in the Olympics."
responses.intersex: Use "intersex" to describe someone born with chromosomes, genitalia and/or reproductive organs that fall outside standard definitions of male and female: "She is one of the intersex athletes speaking out about the new rules." Do not use the term "hermaphrodite." "intersex", "inter-sex", "inter sex", "hermaphrodite" "intersex", "inter-sex", "inter sex", "hermaphrodite" intersex
responses.county: Capitalize "county" when you use it as part of the proper name of a county: "Los Angeles County is America's most populous county." Lowercase it when not using it as part of a proper noun: "The county of Los Angeles is America's most populous county." "county" county
responses.nsfw: "NSFW" is a common abbreviation for "not safe for work." It's generally accepted lingo on the internet, so it's acceptable on first reference on social media. In other copy, write out the phrase. Do not add periods in any context, and if you're quoting written material, format it as you see it written: "'I'm not a fan of that idea, NSFW,' she texted back."
responses.seder: Capitalize "Seder," a dinner that accompanies Passover: "They were looking forward to their family's Seder all week."
responses.salary: Don't use a hyphen in "base pay" or "base salary": "The initial base salary was lower than she expected."
responses.daycare: Use one word for "daycare": "We wanted to find our son a daycare." "daycare", "day care", "day-care" daycare
responses.thundersnow: Use one word for "thundersnow," the rare weather phenomenon in which snow falls instead of rain during a thunderstorm: "Despite their name, thundersnows are relatively quiet affairs since snow muffles the sound of the thunder." "thundersnow", "thunder snow", "thunder-snow" thundersnow
responses.mouthpiece: Use one word for "mouthpiece": "She accused him of being an uncritical mouthpiece for the party in power." mouthpiece, mouth-piece, mouth piece mouthpiece
responses.peta: PETA stands for People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, but the acronym is acceptable on first reference: "PETA is organizing a rally Friday to protest a new ad campaign featuring fur coats." "PETA", "P.E.T.A.", "People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals" PETA
responses.holocaust: Capitalize "Holocaust" when referring to the genocide of 6 million Jewish people by the Nazis during World War II: "He lost family in the Holocaust." There is a lowercase version of "holocaust" that refers to sacrifice, destruction or mass slaughter, but use great caution in selecting this term to avoid an implied comparison to the well-known genocide.
responses.vlog: A “vlog” is a video blog or video log: “Many YouTubers post daily vlogs about their lives.” "vlog", "video blog", "video log", "vlog", "video blogs", "video logs" vlog
responses.kyiv: Use "Kyiv" to refer to Ukraine's capital city: "Their class went to Kyiv on a field trip." "Kyiv" is the transliteration from Ukrainian to English, while "Kiev" is the transliteration from Russian to English. "Kyiv", "Kiev", "kyev" Kyiv
responses.fema: Spell out "Federal Emergency Management Agency" on first reference and use "FEMA" in subsequent references. responses.vesak: Capitalize "Vesak," the holiday that marks Buddha's birthday: "She was doing good deeds for Vesak." It's also called "Vesak Day," "Day of Vesak" and "Buddha Day." Vesak is celebrated in May or June. "Vesak", "Buddha Day", "buddha’s day" Vesak
responses.chairperson: Use one word for "chairperson," and use it or "chair" instead of "chairman" or "chairwoman": "As chair, she led all the committee meetings." responses.bedsheet: Use one word for "bedsheet": "He realized he forgot to change the bedsheets in the guest room." bedsheet, bed sheet, bed-sheet bedsheet
responses.lausd: The proper name for L.A.'s school district is the Los Angeles Unified School District, which you should use on first reference. "LAUSD" is acceptable on second reference.
responses.fed: Capitalize "Confederacy" and "Confederate" in reference to the Confederate States of America, which seceded from the Union leading up to and during the Civil War: "President Trump criticized NASCAR for banning the Confederate flag from its events." "confederate", "confederacy", "confederate flag" Confederacy

responses.snapchat: Only capitalize the "s" (not the "c") in "Snapchat" when referring to the popular app. Do not capitalize "snap" when referring to the messages users send each other. responses.canvass: “Canvass” refers to examining something, or to seeking political support: “During her congressional campaign, she canvassed her district, going door to door to talking to voters.”
responses.whiskey: Use "whiskey" for the drink: "She would add a little whiskey to her tea when she was sick." "whisky", "whiskey" whiskey

responses.kitty-corner: Use "kitty-corner" to describe objects that are diagonally across from each other: "The building is kitty-corner from the parking lot." Variants of the word include "catty-corner" and "catercorner," but "kitty-corner" is most commonly used. "cattycorner", "catty-corner", "catty corner", "kittycorner", "kitty-corner", "kitty corner", "catercorner", "cater-corner", "cater corner" kitty-corner
responses.scuba: Use two words for "scuba diving" and "scuba diver": "After years of being afraid of the water, they finally conquered the fear by going scuba diving." Fun fact: "Scuba" is an acronym for "self-contained underwater breathing apparatus." "scuba", "s.c.u.b.a." scuba
responses.lmao: LMAO means "laughing my ass off." It's generally accepted lingo on the internet, so it's acceptable on first reference on social media. In other copy, write out the phrase. If you are quoting text where "LMAO" is used, format it as you see in the text and explain the acronym if your audience isn't likely to recognize it: "He responded only by writing, 'LMAO,' which stands for 'laughing my ass off.'"
responses.humankind: Use gender-neutral language instead of using "mankind" to mean all of humankind: "Adapting to climate change will be humankind's next great challenge." "Womankind" is one word: "She said she was sticking up for all of womankind." "humankind", "human-kind", "human kind", "mankind", "man-kind", "man kind", "womankind", "woman-kind", "woman kind" humankind
responses.conservatorship: "Conservator" and "guardian" are legal terms whose meaning can vary by state. They both refer to a person who is legally appointed to care for a child or adult and their affairs: "After their parents died, their aunt became their legal guardian." Check the terminology in the jurisdiction where the conservatorship or guardianship was appointed.
responses.cpr: You can use "CPR" to refer to cardiopulmonary resuscitation in all references.
responses.rnc: The Republican National Committee is the governing body for the Republican Party. You can refer to it as "RNC" (no periods) on second reference. Some people also use "RNC" to refer to the Republican National Convention, which is held in presidential election years. Avoid shortening it to "RNC" so it's not confused with the committee. "rnc", "r.n.c.", "republican national committee", "republican national convention" RNC
responses.funnyperson:
Use one word for “funnyperson,” “funnyman” and “funnywoman” when referring to comedians. Default to gender-neutral language unless the person you are writing about has expressed a particular preference or their gender identity is well known: “Chelsea Handler used to have late-night show, and more recently, the funnywoman was on tour to promote her latest book.” Only "funnyman" is widely recognized as a word, but extending the recognition to “funnyperson” and “funnywoman” allows for greater parity. "funnywoman", "funny-woman", "funny woman",
"funnyman", "funny-man", "funny man",
"funnyperson", "funny-person", "funny person" funnyperson
responses.breakdance: Use one word for "breakdance" and "breakdancing": "She wanted to sign up for breakdancing lessons." "breakdance", "break dance", "break-dance", "breakdancing", "break-dancing", "break dancing", "breakdancer", "break dancer", "break-dancer" breakdance
responses.passover: Capitalize "Passover" in all uses: "She went home to celebrate Passover with her family."
